item.title: Europython 2014
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: Crata Data will be at Europython this year. Join our CTO Bernd on 23 July, 2-5pm for a training on "Test driven development of a horizontal scaling REST-Service with Pyramids, Crate and SQLAlchemy" . You will learn about how a simple application can be developed and tested in a sandboxed environment and then deployed to a multi-node cluster leaveraging a shared nothing data store. Our goal is to make any computer in the room part of the cluster to provide compute and storage power to our service.
item.excerpt:encoded: Crata Data will be at Europython this year. Join our CTO Bernd on 23 July, 2-5pm for a training on "Test driven development of a horizontal scaling REST-Service with Pyramids, Crate and SQLAlchemy"

item.title: Omniti Surge
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: [vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Meet Jodok at Surge where he'll talk about Crate as a Backend of the Internet of Things: In this talk, he will discuss the ideal data store architecture for the Internet of Things (or any data intensive application), its requirement for massively scalable horizontal scaling, the different approaches to solving query speed issues and more. He will then show how open source Crate Data addresses these issues with its datastore. He will also cover some design choices under the Crate Data hood: allowing SQL queries vs. full ANSI SQL, dealing with spatial data, joins and nested objects, and additional architecture and roadmap choices. Interested in learning more about Crate? Follow @CrateIO or download Crate and try it yourself![/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 24-26 September 2014 Location: Washington, D.C. Event Site Speaker Presentation[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]
item.excerpt:encoded: Meet Jodok at Omniti Surge- the Scalability and Performance conference. He'll talk about Crate as a scaling infrastructure: A Backend for the Internet of Things.

item.title: Codetalks
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: [vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Triff Jodok bei code.talks in seinem Talk "Man nehme: Facebook Presto, Lucene/Elasticsearch und eine verteilte SQL Engine". Mittlerweile ist jeder Entwickler mit großen Datenmengen konfrontiert. Es gibt eine Vielzahl von Technologien um (teilweise) strukturierte Daten und binäre Objekte zu verwalten, es ist jedoch sehr schwierig diesen Zoo von Technologien zu beherrschen und zu skalieren. Crate Data kombiniert in einem einfach zu benutzenden Package die Vorteile von SQL, Search und semi-strukturierten Dokumenten.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 9-10 October 2014 Location: Hamburg, Germany Event Site Speaker Presentation[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]
item.excerpt:encoded: Dieses Jahr spricht unser CEO Jodok bei code.talks: "Man nehme: Facebook Presto, Lucene/Elasticsearch und eine verteilte SQL Engine"

item.title: Strata & Hadoop World
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: [vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Join CrateIO CEO Jodok Batlogg at his talk "Super Simple Internet of Things Backend: Persistence post Hadoop with Crate". The backend has not only to deal with a constant parallel inflow of data, but even more important: to process lots of ad-hoc events being forwarded from sensors as they happen. Unfortunately traditional infrastructure isn’t designed to handle this kind of workload: In this talk Jodok will describe how we solved this challenge with two horizontally scaling components – Crate (Persistence Layer) and Twitter Storm (Event processing). Crate is a developer-friendly, distributed data store. It is Open Source and makes real time SQL queries on large data sets super simple. Jodok will cover all the pitfalls and learnings on our way to building a productive system. The first scaling issues, the architectural decisions at the beginning, but also about the development process with test-driven development but also interesting code snippets and the outcome of the load tests. Interested in learning more about Crate? Follow @CrateIO or download Crate and try it yourself![/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 15-17 October 2014 Location: New York, New York Event Site Speaker Presentation[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]
item.excerpt:encoded: Come join our CEO Jodok at his talk at this year's Strata & Hadoop World Conference: “Super Simple Internet of Things Backend: Persistence post Hadoop with Crate Data”

item.title: Pioneers Festival
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Join CrateIO at the Pioneers Festival 2014! We have been selected from over 1.000 startups to be among the TOP 50 Pioneer Challenge Finalists and therefore are able to pitch in front of more than 250 investors in Vienna. What is Pioneers all about? Pioneers is all about pioneers. WHAT'S A PIONEER YOU ASK? Fair enough. For us a pioneer is somebody who
  • pushes the borders of what is possible
  • has a vision for our future
  • and most important of all someone who uses the power of technology, science and entrepreneurship to improve our daily lives. Learn about our pioneer work: Crate, a super simple backend for data-intensive applications, offers a solution for the future of data management.
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 29-30 October 2014 Location: Vienna, Austria Event Site[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]
item.excerpt:encoded: Crate will be represented at the Pioneers Festival 2014. Join us for some inspiring 2 days.

item.title: The Summit
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: [vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Meet Crate at this year's The Summit - described as “the best technology conference on the planet”. The Summit is different, and that difference works for most people from the biggest Fortune 500 companies to the smallest and most exciting startups. Technology is changing the world faster and further than at any point in human history. The Summit brings those responsible for that change together because it's important to understand what that change means for our businesses and societies. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 4-6 November 2014 Location: Dublin, Ireland Event Site[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]
item.excerpt:encoded: Meet Crate at The IoT Summit, Dublin 4-6 Nov 2014 - A standalone Summit described as “the best technology conference on the planet” with it‘s own campus, main stage, workshops, networking events and more by day and by night inside The Summit. Looking forward to seeing you around!

item.title: Strata Conference
item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: [vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]The Future Belongs to Those Who Use Data Successfully At Strata, you'll connect and collaborate with top data experts who share their expertise with the tools, technologies, and techniques that matter. Learn about proven best practices and detailed case studies of successful data projects. Crate Data will be there. Meet Jodok in his talk: "Will the hordes of IoT data bring the post-hadoop era and democratize data stores?"[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 19-21 November 2014 Location: Barcelona, Spain Event Site[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.dc:creator: roni
item.content:encoded: [vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]"We've been using Elasticsearch since 2010 and really wished to use it as primary store. a data store that is as easy to use and scale. we built our distributed SQL engine including the facebook presto SQL parser, added a blob storage layer - and Crate Data was born."[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 24 July 2014 Location: Berlin, Germany Event Site[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: International PHP Conference
item.dc:creator: ewald
item.content:encoded: [vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"] [/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Join CrateIO Developer Sebastian Utz at his talk "3 years after studiVZ...challenges, problems and how to solve them with today's technologies" at the International PHP Conference in Munich. Sebastian Utz was one of the Software Architects at studiVZ and responsible for the scaling of the platform. Basti, who delivered up to 70 percent of the platform features, needed massive workarounds and tweaks to withstand the load of approximately 17 millions of active users. Listen to Sebastian on the 28th of October when he talks about the impact of todays technologies and how he managed to overcome such issues. Interested in learning more about Crate? Follow @CrateIO or download Crate and try it yourself![/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Date: 28-29 October 2014 Location: Munich, Germany Event Site Speaker Presentation[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: Drinkup with Crate.IO, Your Big Data Sherpa
item.dc:creator: ewald
item.content:encoded:
Join us in a beautiful rooftop lounge setting for drinks and snacks, just a few blocks from the Strata Conference.

Come discuss Crate.IO's unique elastic data store with founder and CEO Jodok Batlogg and the Crate.IO team. We'll talk about what we're solving and why, as well as how we've approached the problem. We'll be looking to discuss your use cases, get feedback and suggestions. If your startup or business is looking to try Crate, we have Google Cloud Platform resources to give away!

Where & When?

Come to the beautiful Hudson Terrace, a short walk from the convention center anytime between 6 and 8:00pm on Thursday. The address is 621 West 46th, between 11th & 12th Avenues, and we'll be on the rooftop lounge enjoying views of the Hudson and the USS Interpid. Looking for more information, ask us on Twitter, Facebook, or stop by our booth at the conference.

What is Crate?

Crate is a new breed of database to serve today’s mammoth data needs. Based on the familiar SQL syntax, Crate combines high availability, resiliency, and scalability in a distributed design that allows you to query mountains of data in realtime, not batches. A shared-nothing, fully searchable, document- oriented clustered data store, it's the perfect highly available backend for your web scale services. Semi-structured data alongside binary objects, all accessible via SQL.

Come join us!

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Hudson Terrace, 621 W 46th St, New York, NY 10036

item.title: Company
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
Crate is a shared nothing, fully searchable, massively-scalable document oriented cluster data store. It is dead simple to use.

It is a new kind of data store: a developer's nirvana that combines the well known interface of SQL databases with the document oriented approach of modern NoSQL style databases. It is quick and powerful and ideal for high-growth and data intensive applications.

We believe that open software is better software, and we have seen time and time again how openness enables organizations to achieve extraordinary outcomes with their data.  Crate delivers its software as Open Source, accessible at public open source repository on GitHub. Going forward, we will continue to release open source components of our software and make them available to the public.

Our prior experience was all about working with large data sets; our experience taught us to pay attention to ease of use, from simple installation to massive scale, all with painless operation of huge clusters. Data stores should be simple for developers to use. Crate is already deployed in e-commerce, startup, mobile app, automotive and internet of things companies, and is spreading rapidly. [team picture] Jodok Batlogg, Founder and CEO jodok@crate.io
P +43 664 9636963 Jodok has deep experience and wide recognition for his expertise in open source and big data. He is the former CTO at StudiVZ (Germany's Facebook), the former CTO at Sevenload and CEO of Lovely Systems. He is also a director of the Plone & Zope foundations. Jodok loves his skis and his chainsaw and is an adventurous eater. Christian Lutz, Founder and COO

christian@crate.io P +43 676 5 000 144

Christian is a succesful builder of software companies, including enterprise delivery platforms and big consumer portals. He was the co-Founder and COO of the Impossible Project (owner of the last Polaroid factory; bringing Instant Photography back), CEO of ucp morgen, SVP Qpass Inc, CEO at uboot.com & sms.at and President Fatfoogoo. Christian is a serial entrepreneur, freerider and mountaineer at heart. Bernd Dorn, Founder and CTO bernd@crate.io Bernd is Crate's hardcore architect and hacker with more than a decade of experience in distributed systems, enterprise data store solutions and open source. Before Crate Bernd led the technical team of Lovely systems, building big data solutions for many enterprises. Whatever Bernd starts he excels in, be it kite surfing, tennis, building his house or designing Crate. Board of Directors: In addition to Jodok Batlogg and Christian Lutz, our Board of Directors consists of: Nikolaj Nyholm
is a partner at Sunstone and the quintessential university dropout turned technology entrepreneur. At Sunstone, Nikolaj has invested in open source, gaming and web service companies with engagements in Neo Technology, Podio, MakieLab and Seriously to mention a few.
Nikolaj joined Sunstone in 2010 from image recognition company Polar Rose (acquired by Apple), and previously founded Speednames/Ascio (acquired by Group NBT); Imity (acquired by Zyb/Vodafone); and Organic Network, a now-defunct Wi-Fi startup whose legacy is OpenWRT.org, the leading open source Wi-Fi project.  Gil Dibner
joined DFJ Esprit after eight years of venture capital experience in the United States, Europe, and Israel. Prior to DFJ Esprit, Gil helped lead Index Venture’s seed investment activity in their London office, working with companies across Europe, the US, and Israel. Before joining Index, Gil was a principal with Gemini Israel Ventures, a $200M venture capital fund based in Tel Aviv. There, he led investments in The Gifts Project (acquired by Ebay), JFrog, and LoyalBlocks. Prior to that, as a principal at Genesis Partners, also based in Tel Aviv, Gil was very actively involved in a number of investments including Yedda (acquired by AOL), Innovid, SiSense, and Profitect. Tom Peruzzi,
Founder of @aicooma, advisor to different digital startups in Mid Europe and Russia, micro-investor in cool digital stuff delivers strong business and tec background. Tom started and built aicooma, an operations consulting company for digital and media in Europe with all major players as customers, with an exit in 2011. He then successfully invested in several companies (avocadostore, vater hostcom, gpixs360) and helped them build business, adequate technology and grow. As interim CTO Tom helped building one of the first commercial IoT devices in Europe.     Investors: [table] - logo and text Sunstone Capital
Headquartered in Copenhagen, Sunstone Capital is an early-stage Life Science and Technology venture capital company investing in European start-up companies with strong potential to achieve global success in their markets. Since our establishment in 2007, we have built a strong portfolio currently totaling 50 companies and have completed several successful trade sales and IPOs. With approximately EUR 700 million in funds under management, Sunstone is today one of the leading and most active independent venture capital investors in the European and Nordic market.   DFJ Esprit DFJ Esprit, member of the The DFJ Network of Partner Funds is a unique global venture capital model providing global reach through local presence. It encompasses over 140 venture capital professionals, in more than 30 cities throughout the US, Asia (including China and India), Europe, Israel, South America, and Russia, with more than 600 portfolio companies funded and over $7 billion of capital under management.
DFJ Esprit is a single team of partners all of whom benefit from and contribute to the success of our investments. We are entrepreneurs ourselves and we are proud to have built our firm to its current size and are passionate about continually moving forward, which means backing winning companies and doing everything we can to help them achieve and exceed their ambitions.

item.title: Community
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row padding="0" ts_row_break_parents="4" ts_row_zindex="0" ts_row_min_height="100" ts_row_parallax_type="up" ts_row_parallax_speed="20" enable_mobile="false" padding_top="30" padding_bottom="30" ts_row_bg_position="top" ts_row_bg_size_standard="cover" ts_row_bg_size_parallax="150%" ts_row_bg_repeat="no-repeat" margin_left="0" margin_right="0" gradient_angle="0" gradient_color_start="#cccccc" gradient_start_offset="0" gradient_color_end="#cccccc" gradient_end_offset="100" video_mute="true" video_loop="false" video_start="false" video_stop="true" video_controls="true" video_raster="false" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000"][vc_column][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

The Crate Open Source Project

[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

What is Crate?

Crate is an elastic SQL Data Store. It is ideal for data intensive applications and combines the well known SQL interface with the document oriented approach of modern NoSQL/MongoDB-style databases - the ideal middle ground for many developers. Crate Data is quick and powerful and massively scalable. The Crate Data open source project was launched in 2013 and today presents the simplest and most powerful option for any developer building a data intensive application. Crate Technology is the company responsible for keeping the momentum behind the Crate project. Crate remains 100% open.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row padding="0" el_class="project-box"][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="discuss"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Discuss Crate

Join the Crate discussion through community supported forums such as, StackOverflow or IRC. We also offer paid support. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="groups"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Mailing list

Get updates about the Crate.IO project, any interesting write-ups and meetups by joining our mailing list on Google Groups.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="mailling"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Newsletter

Our monthly newsletter announcing new features, events, and Crate community news.[gravityform id="2" name="newsletter-short" title="false" description="false" ajax="true"][/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row padding="0" el_class="project-box"][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="code"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Code Crate

Check out Crate on GitHub and start hacking, building tools and drivers that help other developers. Here are some guidelines on what you need to do before you contribute. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="ask"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Ask anything

You can email us directly at support@crate.io [/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="connect"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Connect with Crate

You can report issues or request features by opening a request on GitHub. [/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row padding="0" el_class="project-box"][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="youtube"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

On YouTube

Check out videos and presentations on our YouTube channel.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="groups"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Crate Groups

You can join or start a Crate user group to network and learn about Crate.IO. If there isn't a Crate user group near you, contact us and we will help you get started.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3" el_class="learn"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Learn Crate

Access the Crate.IO documentation for information about getting started with Crate or to deepen your knowledge of it. You can also join one of our events near you.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row padding="0"][vc_column][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Open Source

We are proud to stand on the shoulders of Open Source giants, of which the most prominent are: Presto: The SQL parser from Presto. We love the clean architecture and modern Java code. Presto is a distributed SQL Query Engine for Big Data by Facebook. Elasticsearch: The transport protocol, cluster discover, Lucene integration and much more of Elasticsearch. Developed by Elasticsearch & Shay Bannon. Netty: much of the credit for speed goes to Netty. An asynchronous event-driven network application framework for rapid development of maintainable high performance protocol servers & clients. Developed by the Netty project team. Lucene: The Ultra-fast search library Apache Lucene that sets the standard for search and indexing performance. Developed by The Apache Software Foundation. We’re happy to give back to the community and make Crate available under the Apache Version 2.0 license. See our notice file for a complete list of Open Source Software we are using. To be able to serve enterprise customers and be a sustainable business, Crate offers commercial licenses, add-ons enterprise support and services.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: crate data, elasticsearch with SQL, SQL over elasticsearch, real time, realtime, real-time, SQL, MongoDB with blob, elasticsearch with blob, lucene, apache lucene, netty, open source, data store, document data base, blob, blob storage, shared nothing, NoSQL, big data, cluster, node, python, ruby, node,js, java, geospatial, SQLalchemy, query, index

Crate.IO has built a new breed of database to serve today’s mammoth data needs. Based on the familiar SQL syntax, Crate combines high availability, resiliency, and scalability in a distributed design that allows you to query mountains of data in realtime, not batches. We solve your data scaling problems and make administration a breeze. Easy to scale, simple to use.

item.title: Terms of Service
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
Acceptance of terms

Thank you for visiting CRATE Technology Gmbh’s Crate.io site (the “Site”). This Agreement contains the complete terms and conditions that apply when you visit our Site or use choose to browse the contents herein. By using this Site, you agree to be bound by its terms of use and shall comply thereof. “We,” “Our”, “Us”, “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" or “Crate Technology” means CRATE Technology Gmbh.

Editing, Deleting and Modification

We may edit, delete or modify any of the terms and conditions contained in this Agreement, at any time and in our sole discretion, by posting a notice or a new agreement on our Site. YOUR CONTINUED VISIT IN OUR WEBSITE FOLLOWING OUR POSTING OF A CHANGE NOTICE OR NEW AGREEMENT ON OUR SITE WILL CONSTITUTE BINDING ACCEPTANCE OF THE CHANGE.

Accuracy, Completeness and Timeliness of Information

Crate Technology is not responsible if information made available on this Site is not accurate, complete or current. The material on this Site is provided for general information only and should not be relied upon or used as the sole basis for making decisions without consulting primary, more accurate, more complete or more timely sources of information. Any reliance on the material on this site is at your own risk. This Site may contain certain historical information which are definitely not current and is provided for reference only. We reserve the right to modify the contents of this site at any time without obligation on our end to update any information on the Site. You understand and agree that it is your responsibility to monitor changes to the Site.

License and Site Access

Crate Technology grants you a limited license to access and make personal use of this Site and not to download or modify it, or any portion of it, except with express written consent from our company. This Site or any portion of this Site may not be reproduced, duplicated, copied, sold, resold, visited, or otherwise exploited for any commercial purpose without express written consent from our company. The right to access our corporate website does not include any resale or commercial use of our Site or its contents nor allows you to download or copy any account information for the benefit of another merchant. Any unauthorized use terminates the permission or license granted by Crate Technology.

Links

You shall not use our company logo or other proprietary graphic to link to this Site without the express written permission of Crate Technology, please visit also our “Trademarks-Section”. Further, you may not frame any trademark, logo or other proprietary information including the Images Content, without our express written consent. We make no claim or representation regarding, and accepts no responsibility for, directly or indirectly, the quality, content, nature or reliability of third-party websites accessible by hyperlink from the Site, or websites linking to the Site. Such sites are not under the control of our company and we shall not responsible for the contents of any linked site or any link contained in a linked site, or any review, changes or updates to such sites. You hereby acknowledge and agree that we are not responsible for the availability of such external websites or resources, its content including, without limitation, any link contained in such content, or any changes or updates to such content. If you decide to access links to third-party websites, you do so at your own risk. Any concerns regarding any external link should be directed to the relevant site administrator or web master.

Disclaimers

YOUR USE OF THIS SITE IS AT YOUR SOLE RISK. THE SITE IS PROVIDED ON AN “AS IS” AND “AS AVAILABLE” BASIS. WE RESERVE THE RIGHT TO RESTRICT OR TERMINATE YOUR ACCESS TO THE SITE OR ANY FEATURE OR PART THEREOF AT ANY TIME. item.title: Privacy Policy
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
Applicability

This privacy policy applies to the use of crate.io. We highly value your privacy and make this policy easily available throughout our site to assist you in understanding the handling of information in the course of using this site.

Registration and Use of Personal Information

Registration is not required in order to use or access this website. However, this site may make forums, blogs, message boards or similar available to its users. You may be required to register for these features, particularly if you wish to leave comments or provide articles. If you do register, and in the process provide us with personally identifiable information, rest assured that any such information you provide will not be shared with any third-party organization except with your express consent. Please note that if you post comments or articles to any forum, blog or message board on this site, any personally identifiable information you provide in those comments or articles may be read, collated and used by anyone viewing them. As such, we are not responsible for personally identifiable information you may choose to make available through these channels. We also provide visitors to our website the opportunity to opt-in to receive communications from us. In this case, we ask the visitor for his or her email address. These communications will include our monthly newsletter, product promotions and any other information that we feel may be pertinent to the visitor. You may opt out of receiving any, or all, of these communications by clicking on the “unsubscribe” link in any email we send to you or by replying to any email we send you and entering the word UNSUBSCRIBE in the subject line. Again, if you provide us with your email address and/or name for the purposes of receiving communications from us, this information will not be shared with any third-party organization except with your express consent.

Access to Personally Identifiable Information

If your personally identifiable information changes, or if you no longer wish us to possess your information, you may request correction, updating, or deletion of your information by emailing us at office@crate.io.

Links to Other Websites

This website may contain links to other sites that are not controlled in any way by us. Please be aware of this when you click on any such links; we are not responsible for the privacy practices and/or policies of any website other than our own. Consequently, we strongly suggest that you review the privacy policy of every website you visit, whether or not they are linked to by our own site.

Security

We follow accepted industry standards to protect any personal information you have provided to us. However, please be aware that no method of electronic storage can ever be 100% secure. Therefore – as is the case with any organization – we are not in a position to guarantee the absolute security of your information.

Cookie

A cookie is a small file which asks permission to be placed on your computer’s hard drive. Once you agree, the file is added and the cookie helps analyze web traffic or lets you know when you visit a particular site. Cookies allow web applications to respond to you as an individual. The web application can tailor its operations to your needs, likes and dislikes by gathering and remembering information about your preferences. We use traffic log cookies to identify which pages are being used. This helps us analyze data about webpage traffic and improve our website in order to tailor it to customer needs. We only use this information for statistical analysis purposes and then the data is removed from the system. Overall, cookies help us provide you with a better website by enabling us to monitor which pages you find useful and which you do not. A cookie in no way gives us access to your computer or any information about you, other than the data you choose to share with us. You can choose to accept or decline cookies. Most web browsers automatically accept cookies, but you can usually modify your browser setting to decline cookies if you prefer. This may prevent you from taking full advantage of the website.

Legal Disclaimer

We reserve the right to disclose your personally identifiable information as required by law and when we believe that disclosure is necessary to protect our rights and/or to comply with a judicial proceeding, court order or legal process served on our website.

Special Note to International Users

The website is hosted in the European Union and is intended for and directed to users in the whole world. If you are accessing the Website from the USA, Asia, or any other region with laws or regulations governing personal data collection, use, and disclosure, that differ from European Union and Austrian laws, please be advised that through your continued use of the Website, which is governed by E.U. privacy law, this Privacy Policy, and our Terms of Service, you may be transferring your personal information to the European Union and you consent to that transfer.

Changes and Updates to this Privacy Policy

This Privacy Policy may be revised periodically and this will be reflected by the date below. Please revisit this page to stay aware of any changes. In general, we only use your personal information in the manner described in the Privacy Policy in effect when we received the personal information you provided. Your continued use of the Website constitutes your agreement to this Privacy Policy and any future revisions. For revisions to this Privacy Policy that may be materially less restrictive on our use or disclosure of the personal information you have already provided to us, we will attempt to obtain your consent before implementing such revisions with respect to such information. If you have any questions about our privacy policy, please contact us office@crate.io. This privacy policy was last updated on February 16th, 2014.

item.title: Trademark Guidelines
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
Crate is a trademark of CRATE Technology Gmbh, registered in the E.U. and in other countries. We are sure you understand that our trademarks are valuable assets of the company. Developers who want to use any Crate trademark or service mark in their promotional, instructional or marketing material or make references to our material online or in hard copy need to follow these guidelines.

If you use a Crate Trademark

  • you acknowledge that Crate is the sole owner of that trademark.
  • you agree not to interfere with Crate´s rights in the trademark anywhere in the world.
  • you agree that any goodwill derived from using any Cratetrademark inures to the benefit of Crate
  • use of the Crate logo is reserved only for licensees as per written license agreement.
  • “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" word marks may not be part of a company or product name.
  • “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" word marks must be smaller and less prominent than your product/service name
  • If you reference with “works with” or “compatible to” “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" your product/service must actually fully function with Crate.
  • Do not use “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" in a way that creates the impression of affiliation or endorsement of Crate.
  • Do not use “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" as domain name or part of a social media name.
  • Do not use “Crate”, “Crate Data”, "Crate.IO" in connection with any unlawful activity or on any unlawful site.
  • when you distribute with Crate please add the following text “Crate is a trademark of Crate Technology Gmbh, registered in the E.U. and in other countries.
Please contact us for any question you may have.

item.title: Overview
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row padding="0" ts_row_break_parents="4" ts_row_zindex="0" ts_row_min_height="100" ts_row_parallax_type="up" ts_row_parallax_speed="20" enable_mobile="false" padding_top="30" padding_bottom="30" ts_row_bg_position="top" ts_row_bg_size_standard="cover" ts_row_bg_size_parallax="150%" ts_row_bg_repeat="no-repeat" margin_left="0" margin_right="0" gradient_angle="0" gradient_color_start="#cccccc" gradient_start_offset="0" gradient_color_end="#cccccc" gradient_end_offset="100" video_mute="true" video_loop="false" video_start="false" video_stop="true" video_controls="true" video_raster="false" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Crate: Your Elastic Data Store

Crate.io is revolutionizing the way you build scalable backends for web scale applications. Instead of nailing together different services to build your backend data store and wondering how to scale when your data grows from millions to billions, Crate offers the simplicity and scalability you need from the outset. Crate is a distributed data store. Simply install Crate directly on your application servers and make the big centralized database a thing of the past. Crate takes care of synchronization, sharding, scaling, and replication even for mammoth data sets. If a node becomes unavailable, Crate self-heals and rebalances the cluster automatically. Our guiding principle is simplicity. Crate is simple to set up, scale, and query in real time using SQL. Crate can be installed in the cloud, or using on-premise commodity hardware.  Use our Docker image to simplify installations across your entire cluster. [/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="50"][vc_row_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" el_class="link-box"]

Get started with Crate right now »

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" el_class="link-box"]

Go in-depth with Crate’s features »

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][vc_column_inner width="1/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" el_class="link-box"]

Use Cases: How Crate can help you »

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column_inner][/vc_row_inner][vc_separator height="50"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Scalable. Simple. Fast.

Crate is a distributed system that runs on one machine or a cluster of machines. Crate comes in one complete install package. It includes solid established open source components (Presto, Elasticsearch, Lucene, Netty) and extends those with added core functionality like read/write support, SQL language, dashboard and query console.[/vc_column_text][vc_single_image image="2266" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="medium" el_class="smallimage" img_link_large="yes"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]All nodes in a Crate Cluster are equal, a shared-nothing architecture. That makes configuration really easy. Furthermore, Crate is able to utilize all cluster resources for all functions if needed. On each node, the Handler Side component receives client requests and processes them. After parsing, SQL queries are analyzed and executed in a distributed manner. To calculate the final result, remote nodes collect intermediate results and merge them in the next phase. To make BLOB delivery even faster, nodes are able to stream results directly as well.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Crate vs. A Zoo of Technologies

Crate.IO has built a new breed of database to serve today’s mammoth data needs. Based on the familiar SQL syntax, Crate combines high availability, resiliency, and scalability in a distributed design that allows you to query mountains of data in realtime, not batches. It is also 100 % open source. We built it so developers with a data intensive back-end won’t need to “glue” several technologies together to store documents, blobs and support real-time search. We also wanted to help developers avoid the manual work associated with tuning, sharding, replication and other operations required to keep a large de-normalized data store in good shape. We wanted a simple, failure-tolerant and massively scalable data store anyone can use, on a single machine, many machines or on the cloud.[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="20"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]A data store for data-intensive apps would need to be persistent, horizontally scalable and support these five requirements: (1) store documents, (2) blobs, (3) find them again (4) run queries (analytics) and (5) allow making straightforward changes to the data structure if needed. This is where the medley of technologies comes in. Couldn’t developers just glue together several technologies and get at the same results? Here are some examples:
  • MongoDB + ElasticSearch + GridFS GridFS would support blob storage, ElasticSearch the search and MongoDB would do the rest. Making data structure changes may be difficult though and scaling and multi node environments may be difficult to manage.
  • Riak + Solr + Rados Rados for blob storage, Solr for searches and Riak for the rest. This is very similar to the first option and likewise shares its issues.
  • CouchDb (document store and analystics) + ElasticSearch (search) + HDFS (blob storage, archiving) + Hadoop (analytics and changes) This solution would exhibit many of the issues associated with Hadoop and with its suitability for heavy read and write workloads.
[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="20"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Let’s see how Crate deals with these 5 requirements, while also supporting a self-healing and self-configuring data store.
  1. Storing Documents Crate.IO stores documents through the built in functionality of Lucene and ElasticSearch. Crate adds dump/restore functionality for major version upgrades which brings point-in-time-recovery to the next level.
  2. Storing Blobs Blob storage is done transparently, using the Crate blob implementation, which is built on the elasticsearch cluster semantics for distribution, replication and allocation. It simply stores blobs directly on the user-space filesystem.
  3. Finding Documents Crate uses Elasticsearch for search – that’s pretty much the best there is for speed.
  4. Real time data analytics using SQL Crate.IO enables real time data analytics using SQL through the distributed query analyzer, planner and execution engine. This adds advanced grouping and sorting functionality to provide SQL like “group by … having ..” and “order by” functionality. Think of Map/Reduce, but in real-time.
  5. Making changes without re-doing everything Remember the good old days when restructuring an entire relational database was possible by using a single SQL script? Crate implements that functionality by borrowing the ability to put the result of a query directly into one or more indexes. This requirement becomes even more eminent on document based databases, where data is often stored in a highly denormalized format.
[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="20"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Requirements

  • Linux, Mac OS X or Windows
  • Java 7
  • Python (for the command line client)
[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="20"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Clients and Tools

Crate is shipping with a built-in Administration Interface. The Command Line interface (Crate Shell – CraSh) allows interactive queries. Crate’s Python client is most advanced and features SQLAlchemy integration.[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="20"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Screenshots from the Administration Interface

[/vc_column_text][rev_slider_vc alias="ui2"][/vc_column][/vc_row]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: crate data, elasticsearch with SQL, SQL over elasticsearch, real time, realtime, real-time, SQL, MongoDB with blob, elasticsearch with blob, lucene, apache lucene, netty, open source, data store, document data base, blob, blob storage, shared nothing, NoSQL, big data, cluster, node, python, ruby, node,js, java, geospatial, SQLalchemy, query, index

Crate.IO has built a new breed of database to serve today’s mammoth data needs. Based on the familiar SQL syntax, Crate combines high availability, resiliency, and scalability in a distributed design that allows you to query mountains of data in realtime, not batches. We solve your data scaling problems and make administration a breeze. Easy to scale, simple to use.

item.title: Download
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row padding="0" ts_row_break_parents="4" ts_row_zindex="0" ts_row_min_height="100" ts_row_parallax_type="up" ts_row_parallax_speed="20" enable_mobile="false" padding_top="30" padding_bottom="30" ts_row_bg_position="top" ts_row_bg_size_standard="cover" ts_row_bg_size_parallax="150%" ts_row_bg_repeat="no-repeat" margin_left="0" margin_right="0" gradient_angle="0" gradient_color_start="#cccccc" gradient_start_offset="0" gradient_color_end="#cccccc" gradient_end_offset="100" video_mute="true" video_loop="false" video_start="false" video_stop="true" video_controls="true" video_raster="false" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000"][vc_column width="1/3" css=".vc_custom_1417789081943{margin-top: 1px !important;margin-bottom: 1px !important;border-top-width: 1px !important;border-bottom-width: 1px !important;}" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000" el_class="download-column"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Get:

Latest stable release: [types field="stable_version" id=""][/types] Released on [types field="release_date" id=""][/types] Download .tar.gz[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="20"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Testing

Testing builds of Crate should be used for testing upcoming new features only and should not be used in production. Crate Testing Release Nightly builds of Crate are provided for testing purposes only. You can download the latest builds here.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Try:

Use our easy one-step command to launch Crate in a sandboxed environment: Hint: Launch it on two or more machine in the same network :) 
bash -c "$(curl -L try.crate.io)"
Insert your data or play around with the live Twitter stream as sample data. (Requires Java 7 on OS X or Linux. Step-by-step instructions available).[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Play:

We built a Crate Cube - a condensed miniaturized cluster - to allow you to try out Crate without having to download or install anything. Open Admin-Dashboard[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row padding="0" ts_row_break_parents="4" ts_row_zindex="0" ts_row_min_height="100" ts_row_parallax_type="up" ts_row_parallax_speed="20" enable_mobile="false" padding_top="30" padding_bottom="30" ts_row_bg_position="top" ts_row_bg_size_standard="cover" ts_row_bg_size_parallax="150%" ts_row_bg_repeat="no-repeat" margin_left="0" margin_right="0" gradient_angle="0" gradient_color_start="#cccccc" gradient_start_offset="0" gradient_color_end="#cccccc" gradient_end_offset="100" video_mute="true" video_loop="false" video_start="false" video_stop="true" video_controls="true" video_raster="false" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Install Crate for Production

If you want to install Crate onto your Linux System, we recommend to use our prebuilt packages. Right now we support RedHat Enterprise Linux 6 and compatible distributions as well as Ubuntu and Arch Linux. Let our 1-step installer configure the appropriate package repository and install Crate Data: 
bash -c "$(curl -L install.crate.io)"
After downloading, and installing, the Crate Service will be started and Crate will listen on Port 4200.[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Alternatively follow our Step-by-step instructions for:[/vc_column_text][vc_tabs size="small" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][vc_tab title="Docker" tab_id="1409666834367-3-5" icon="none"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Docker Image

We host our Docker images for Crate Data on Docker's own Docker Hub Registry. After installing Docker you can pull the latest image simply by: 
docker pull crate/crate:latest
To pull an image with a certain Crate version you can do: 
docker pull crate/crate:X.Y.Z
where X.Y.Z is the version number of Crate. There are Docker images available from version 0.41.4 For further information please refer to the docker-crate Github repository.[/vc_column_text][/vc_tab][vc_tab title="RHEL/YUM" tab_id="1406114802-1-81" icon="none"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Use our Yum Repository

The Crate Team maintains the official YUM repositories for RPM-based releases. It is supported on Linux Distributions such as RedHat Enterprise Linux 6, CentOS 6 or Scientific Linux 6.

How to enable the CRATE YUM repository

All CRATE packages are signed with GPG. To verify the packages the public key must be installed to the system. After that, you can install the .rpm containing the YUM repository definition on your system. 
sudo rpm --import https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/yum/RPM-GPG-KEY-crate
sudo rpm -Uvh https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/yum/6/x86_64/crate-release-6.5-1.noarch.rpm
Retrieving https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/yum/6/x86_64/crate-release-6.5-1.noarch.rpm
Preparing...                ########################################### [100%]
   1:crate-release          ########################################### [100%]
Make sure you are allowed to sudo. You can verify the GPG key, the installation of the repository and get details about available packages: 
rpm -qa gpg* | grep gpg-pubkey-06f6eaeb-52cbcb20
gpg-pubkey-06f6eaeb-52cbcb20

yum repolist | grep crate
repo id  repo name                                       status
crate    CRATE Packages for Enterprise Linux 6 - x86_64       2

yum info crate
Available Packages
Name        : crate
Arch        : x86_64
Version     : ...
Release     : 1
Size        : 42 M
Repo        : crate
Summary     : A shared nothing, fully searchable document oriented cluster datastore
URL         : https://crate.io/

Unstable/Testing releases

The Crate Testing repository is disabled by default. It contains development builds and is frequently updated. The packages are waiting for feedback from testers as to their functionality and stability. Packages in this repository will come and go during the development period, so it should not be left enabled or used on production systems. If you want to enable the Testing repo on your server, set enabled=1 in /etc/yum.repos.d/crate.repo[/vc_column_text][/vc_tab][vc_tab title="Ubuntu" tab_id="1406114802-2-75" icon="none"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Ubuntu Personal Package Archive (PPA)

We build packages for the Ubuntu versions Lucid Lync, Saucy Salamander and Precise Pangolin. They are available on our Launchpad page. To enable the Repository on your machine simply add the PPA: 
sudo apt-get install python-software-properties
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:crate/stable
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install crate

Unstable/Testing releases

The Crate Testing Repository contains development builds and is frequently updated. The packages are waiting for feedback from testers as to their functionality and stability. Packages in this repository will come and go during the development period, so it should not be left enabled or used on production systems. To enable the Testing Repository on your machine add the PPA: 
sudo apt-get install python-software-properties
sudo add-apt-repository ppa:crate/testing
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install crate
[/vc_column_text][/vc_tab][vc_tab title="Debian" tab_id="1417787492864-4-10" icon="none"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Debian Packages

We provide Debian packages for the Wheezy distribution (7.x). They are hosted on our own repository. Installing Crate from our repository requires just a few steps: 
# install https support for apt
sudo apt get install apt-transport-https
# download and install gpg key
wget https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/apt/DEB-GPG-KEY-crate
sudo apt-key add DEB-GPG-KEY-crate
# add repository to sources
echo "
deb https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/apt/stable/ wheezy main
deb-src https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/apt/stable/ wheezy main" >> /etc/apt/sources.list
# update sources and install crate
sudo apt-get update
sudo apt-get install crate

Testing Releases

Testing releases of Crate are also available for Debian. Use the following source URLs: 
deb https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/apt/testing/ wheezy main
deb-src https://cdn.crate.io/downloads/apt/testing/ wheezy main
[/vc_column_text][/vc_tab][vc_tab title="Arch Linux" tab_id="1406114935129-2-1" icon="none"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Arch Linux Arch User Repository (AUR)

Since some of the Crate developers use Arch Linux, we also publish our buildfiles for Arch Linux AUR. Installing packages from the AUR is a relatively simple process (Full instructions are available on the Arch Linux Wiki). Make sure build base-devel is installed (pacman -S --needed base-devel) 
mkdir ~/builds
cd ~/builds
curl -O https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/cr/crate/crate.tar.gz
tar xzvf crate.tar.gz
cd crate
Build and install the package: 
makepkg -si
AUR Helpers add seamless access to the AUR. They vary in their features but can ease in searching, fetching, building, and installing from PKGBUILDs found in the AUR. All of these scripts can be found in the AUR.[/vc_column_text][/vc_tab][/vc_tabs][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Clients and Utilities

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="2548" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Java

Our Java distributions are hosted on Bintray and available through JCenter. Note that the JDBC driver requires Crate 0.38.0 or newer.
  • Crate Java Driver (crate-client) Documentation
  • Crate JDBC Driver (crate-jdbc) Documentation
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="2549" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Python

Our Python projects are hosted on Python Packaging Index (PyPI):
  • Crate Python Client (including SQLAlchemy Integration)
  • Crate Shell (CraSh)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="2762" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="253x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Ruby

Our Ruby distributions are hosted on RubyGems. The initial Ruby driver and Activerecord adapter were written by Christoph Klocker.
  • CrateRuby (RubyGems, Github)
  • Activerecord Crate Adapter (RubyGems, Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="3336" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="116x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

PHP

Our PHP packages are hosted on Packagist. There are a PDO driver and a DBAL Driver that depends on the PDO driver.
  • Crate PDO (Packagist, Github)
  • Crate DBAL (Packagist, Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="3335" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="206x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Node.js

There are several drivers for Node.js written by community distributors. They are available via npm.
  • node-crate by @megastef (npm, Github)
  • crate-connect by @herenow (npm, Github)
  • cratejs by @herenow (npm, Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="3333" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="82x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Erlang

Craterl is a full-blown Crate Erlang client written by Matthias Wahl. Craterl brings full SQL support including parameters and bulk operations, full BLOB support, for GET, PUT, DELETE and HEAD requests.
  • craterl (Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="3334" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="59x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Mono/.NET

crate-mono is a Mono/.NET client driver implementing the ADO.NET interface for Crate written by Mathias Fussenegger.
  • crate-mono (Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="3405" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="98x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Go

herenow wrote a Golang driver for Crate that implements the Go sql interface package.
  • go-crate (Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_single_image image="3337" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="70x70"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

dbext.vim

Mathias Fussenegger forked dbext to support Crate.
  • dbext.vim (Github)
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_separator height="50"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_raw_js][/vc_raw_js][/vc_column][/vc_row]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Crate Data is a distributed data storage system that running on a cluster of machines. Scaling as easy and as linear as your webservers or application machines.

item.title: Home
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row el_class="intro"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

CRATE Your Elastic Data Store

We solve your data scaling problems and make administration a breeze. Easy to scale, simple to use.[/vc_column_text][vc_separator height="10"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]Try it now![/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row bg_color="#d4d8db" el_class="video-banners" ts_row_break_parents="4" ts_row_zindex="0" ts_row_min_height="100" ts_row_parallax_type="up" ts_row_parallax_speed="20" enable_mobile="false" padding_top="30" padding_bottom="30" ts_row_bg_position="top" ts_row_bg_size_standard="cover" ts_row_bg_size_parallax="150%" ts_row_bg_repeat="no-repeat" margin_left="0" margin_right="0" gradient_angle="0" gradient_color_start="#cccccc" gradient_start_offset="0" gradient_color_end="#cccccc" gradient_end_offset="100" video_mute="true" video_loop="false" video_start="false" video_stop="true" video_controls="true" video_raster="false" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000"][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="3378" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_link_custom="https://crate.io/blog/crate-io-wins-techcrunch-disrupt-startup-battle-2/"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="3429" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_link_custom="/snowsprint/"][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_single_image image="3383" alignment="center" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_link_custom="/jobs/"][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row bg_color="#263e4d" el_class="dark" padding="10px"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" el_class="crate-github"]

CRATE is open source. It’s hosted, developed and maintained on GitHub

CRATE on GitHub

Or get the source directly with the following git clone https://github.com/crate/crate.git

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row bg_color="#d4d8db" el_class="home-boxes"][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_single_image img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="full" image="2955"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Powerful.

Crate is a powerful, complete backend solution for tabular data, semi-structured records, and binary objects (BLOBs).

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_single_image img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="full" image="182"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Sub-second, super-fast.

Crate is highly available and offers massively parallel access in real-time, enabling sub-second responses on billions of records.

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_single_image img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="full" image="183"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Easy to scale. Simple to use.

Adding nodes on commodity hardware or in the cloud is as simple as a single command in your terminal.

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

News Feed and Blog Posts

[news and posts on homepage][/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Events

[events amount="5" period="future"][/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row bg_color="#263e4d" el_class="twitter-box dark"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row bg_color="#d4d8db"][vc_column width="2/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" el_class="featured"]

Featured In

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][vc_column width="1/3"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Awards

[/vc_column_text][vc_single_image image="2476" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_link="http://gigaom.com/2014/06/18/crate-and-nimboxx-are-the-winners-of-the-2014-structure-launchpad-competition/"][vc_single_image image="3361" img_link_target="_self" css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0" img_size="300x90" img_link_custom="https://eir.cisco.com/"][/vc_column][/vc_row]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: crate data, elasticsearch with SQL, SQL over elasticsearch, real time, realtime, real-time, SQL, MongoDB with blob, elasticsearch with blob, lucene, apache lucene, netty, open source, data store, document data base, blob, blob storage, shared nothing, NoSQL, big data, cluster, node, python, ruby, node,js, java, geospatial, SQLalchemy, query, index

Crate.IO has built a new breed of database to serve today’s mammoth data needs. Based on the familiar SQL syntax, Crate combines high availability, resiliency, and scalability in a distributed design that allows you to query mountains of data in realtime, not batches. We solve your data scaling problems and make administration a breeze. Easy to scale, simple to use.

item.title: How to contribute
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row padding="0" ts_row_break_parents="4" ts_row_zindex="0" ts_row_min_height="100" ts_row_parallax_type="up" ts_row_parallax_speed="20" enable_mobile="false" padding_top="30" padding_bottom="30" ts_row_bg_position="top" ts_row_bg_size_standard="cover" ts_row_bg_size_parallax="150%" ts_row_bg_repeat="no-repeat" margin_left="0" margin_right="0" gradient_angle="0" gradient_color_start="#cccccc" gradient_start_offset="0" gradient_color_end="#cccccc" gradient_end_offset="100" video_mute="true" video_loop="false" video_start="false" video_stop="true" video_controls="true" video_raster="false" animation_scroll="false" animation_speed="2000"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]We are an open source company by heart and we’d love to get your help and support by contributions from our community. This does not only mean code, but also engaging on stackoverflow, usergroups, documentation, submitting bugs and issues and of course feature requests.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Request features and report issues

We are aware that many features have to be added over time. In order to help prioritize we also want to get your feedback. Just open an issue on Github and describe the feature you want and how it should work. If you explain why you’re making the feature request, we may find a way to help you. Before reporting an issue, make sure you use the latest version of Crate and search our issues list on Github, it may be already tracked and in the pipeline. If possible help us in reproducing the bug by delivering a small test case so we can run a test against it.[/vc_column_text][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Contribute code

We appreciate your ideas and help. Before you start to contribute please contact us (e.g. in #crate on Freenode IRC), just to make sure nobody else is already working on that problem or feature. In order to optimize the way things get solved it is best to find the best approach with us before writing too much code – we want your code to get accepted!
  1. Fork and clone the repository Clone the main Crate repository to your local machine.
  2. Start coding The document DEVELOP.rst on GitHub has detailled instructions about how to work on Crate.
  3. Test your changes Run tests to make sure that nothing is broken.
  4. Sign the contributor license agreement (CLA) We are not asking you to give us your copyright, but we need to get your OK to distribute your code without restriction.
  5. Update your local repository with latest Crate code Rebase your branch on top of the latest master branch. We prefer your changes to be squashed into a single commit.
  6. Submit a pull request Update your forked copy of the repository and submit a pull request to our team. Please describe your changes, and if possible refer to the issues solved on the issue list.
  7. Grab a coffee Our team will review the pull request and discuss it internally. We may come back to you. And if things go well pull your request into the code base.
[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row]

item.title: Contact Us
item.dc:creator: azntve
item.content:encoded:
[vc_row padding="0"][vc_column width="1/1"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

Get in touch with the people behind Crate Data:

[/vc_column_text][/vc_column][/vc_row][vc_row][vc_column width="1/2"][vc_column_text css_animation_speed="faster" css_animation_delay="0"]

To connect with the people behind the Crate.IO Project:
